parsetree.*:
<root><template><title>RV</title><part><name>type</name>=<value>command

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> arma3
</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>0.50
</value></part><part><name>arg</name>=<value> global

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> Stamina System

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> Returns fatigue of given unit.

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> '''getFatigue''' unit

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value> unit: [[Object]]

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[Number]]

</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code> value = [[getFatigue]] [[player]];
</code>

</value></part><part><name>x2</name>=<value> <code> [[if]] ([[getFatigue]] [[player]] < 0.5) [[then]] { [[player]] [[sideChat]] "I'm good to go!" };
</code>

</value></part><part><name>seealso</name>=<value> [[setFatigue]], [[enableFatigue]], [[getStamina]]
</value></part></template>

<dl class='command_description'>
<comment><!-- Note Section BEGIN -->
</comment>
<dt class="note">[[User:Killzone_Kid|Killzone_Kid]]<dd class="note">
[[getFatigue]] can be applied to remote unit however it will not read the changes made to unit's fatigue with [[setFatigue]] command. Only natural changes resulting from unit moving will be counted. When applied to local unit, it will read resulting value of natural fatigue combined with artificial changes added locally by [[setFatigue]]. In short, the server wouldn't know the correct value of remote unit's fatigue if you used [[setFatigue]] on the unit prior.<br>

<comment><!-- Note Section END -->
</comment></dl></root>
